Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel - 12th International Workshop on Nanomechanical Sensing (NMC2015); Auckland, New Zealand.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT:

a) Nontechnical

The 12th International Workshop on Nano mechanical Sensing (NMC2015) will be held in July 2015
in Auckland, New Zealand: http://nmc2015.org. We anticipate 150-200 academic and industrial
research scientists from around the world will attend. NMC has been held in Asia, Europe,
and the U. S. annually since 2004. The organization promotes cross- pollination of ideas from
all corners of the globe. The conference consists of oral presentations (invited and juried),
poster sessions, and time for informal networking and discussion. All materials presented
at the meeting are invited to submit a more comprehensive version of their work in a special
edition of the IET journal Micro Nano Letters.

The NMC workshop is focused on interdisciplinary research on and with nanoscale sensors. NMC
started as a "Nano mechanical cantilever" meeting but has grown along with innovations in
Nano mechanics and probing at the nanoscale. NMC Workshops are non-profit academic meetings
which are self-supporting; the meetings rely on contributions and attendee tuition to offset
all expenses. NSF support is requested to assist in keeping the tuition rate as low as possible
to enable a larger number of students and postdoctoral trainees to attend. NMC2015 provides
a single session technical program with the latest research on Nano sensing including renowned
invited speakers, contributed oral and poster presentations and excellent networking opportunities.
NMC aims to promote interaction among researchers in the micro and Nano sensing and device
community interested in addressing high-impact issues in chemical, biological and physical
detection e.g. applications from homeland security and health, to materials research for computing
and energy. An important component of the meeting is discussion and exploration on bringing
this research to the real world. Conference participants hail from major universities and
research facilities in the world.

Technical

Students will be participating in this conference. Attending sessions, and discussing with the researchers in the fields. They will be able to present their technical papers and discuss the latest technology on nanosensors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 13th International Workshop on Nanomechanical Sensing (NMC2016) was held 22 – 24 June, 2016 in Delft, The Netherlands. http://www.nmc-2016.org/. Over 100 academic and industrial research scientists from around the world attended NMC2016. NMC has held meetings in Asia, Europe, and the U. S. annually since 2004. The meeting is dedicated to the cross- pollination of ideas from all corners of the globe and the conference consisted of oral presentations by highly regarded invited speakers from Europe, Americas, and Asia as well as juried papers, and poster presentations. The meeting also included time for informal networking and discussion. All authors who presented at the meeting were invited to submit a more comprehensive version of their work in a special edition of the open access journal Mechanical Sciences.

The Workshop on Nanomechanical Sensing meeting is focused on interdisciplinary research on and with nanoscale sensors. NMC started as the "nano mechanical cantilever" meeting but has grown along with innovations in nanomechanics and probing at the nanoscale. The NMC Workshops are non-profit academic meetings which are self-supporting; the meetings rely on contributions and attendee tuition to offset all expenses. With NSF support we enabled U.S. students and postdoctoral trainees to apply and attend the meeting. Feedback from these students was highly complimentary and all were grateful for the opportunity to open their views on possible research directions. NMC2016 provided a single session technical program with the latest research on nanosensing presented by renowned invited speakers, contributed oral and poster presentations, and excellent networking opportunities. Through the 3-day program of sessions and social events, NMC successfully promoted interaction among researchers in the micro and nano sensing and device community who are interested in addressing some of the high-impact issues in chemical, biological and physical detection e.g. with applications from homeland security and health to materials research for computing and energy systems. The conference participants hailed from major universities and research facilities throughout the United States and the world.

Award data: Applicants were surveyed and given the option to provide demographic data which will only be reported in aggregate. As per discussion with the program director, trainees currently affiliated with a US educational institution were eligibile to apply and receive these awards. 3 applicants were not affiliated with US institutions and were not considered for awards. The remaining 6 awardees all had affiliations with US institutions and all were authors on an NMC paper to be presented at the meeting.

Total Awards ($15000): 5 students and 1 postdoc (3 men and 3 women) were awarded travel grants from the University of California Santa Barbara, Georgia Tech, Stanford University, Florida Institute of Technology and came from departments of Material Science, Mechanical Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Micro/Nanotechnology. One awardee had attended NMC in 2013, three had never attended a technical conference before this one.

Intellectual Merit: The NMC 2016 Workshop disseminated international research and catalyzed innovation in micro and nanotechnology for chemical, biological and physical applications with long term benefit for homeland security and health to materials research for computing and energy systems. The Workshop provided a forum for discussing results, techniques, and devices while simultaneously promoting commercialization in the field. This Workshop also allowed attendees to network within the multidisciplinary nanomechanical sensing community including electrical and mechanical engineers as well as chemists, physicists, and material scientists. Additionally, this forum addressed the needs for commercialization of novel technologies and standardization through the interaction with entrepreneurial specialists, industry members, and government lab researchers.

Broader Impact: The Workshop’s topics addressed topics having broader impact, e.g., advances in micro and nano-enabled technologies offer significant potential for monitoring water, air, and food quality, improved biomedical detection, and fundamental studies of materials to enable next generation computing and energy storage and production, all key topics for the future for the U.S. and internationally. Attendance by young researchers at this meeting has positioned them to contribute to this vital, highly interdisciplinary field.


Last Modified: 08/10/2016
Modified by: Beth L Pruitt
